title: 113_hr5756
content: The Act may be cited as the "Heller Public Firearms Range Act of 2014". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress acknowledges the severe restrictions on the right to keep and bear arms in the District of Columbia, leading to inadequate firearms skills for safety. The importance of safety education and training for using firearms for hunting and self-defense is highlighted, with recognition of the role of the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act in facilitating such education. Richard A. Heller's efforts in advocating for Second Amendment rights in the District of Columbia, culminating in the landmark Supreme Court decision in District of Columbia v. Heller, are commended. SEC. 3 of the Pittman-Robertson Wildlife Restoration Act is amended to include the District of Columbia in apportionment. Section 8A is also amended to address cooperation and payment of funds. The Secretary of the Interior may cooperate with various entities for wildlife restoration projects and hunter safety programs, and apportion funds to Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Virgin Islands. The Secretary of the Interior may apportion funds to Puerto Rico, the District of Columbia, Guam, American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Virgin Islands, with specific percentages allocated for each region. The Secretary may allocate funds to various regions, with specific percentages assigned. The Virgin Islands receive one-sixth of 1 percent of the total amount apportioned. There is a limitation that no cooperating agency should pay more than 25 percent of project costs. Any unspent funds can be carried over to the following year for approved projects in specified regions, or used by the Secretary for the Migratory Bird Conservation Act. The Secretary of the Interior may allocate funds to different regions under the Migratory Bird Conservation Act. If funds were previously apportioned before the enactment of this Act, an additional apportionment will be made to the District of Columbia. The Secretary is also directed to use funds for the construction and operation of an indoor public target range for firearm users. The Secretary of the Interior will allocate funds for an indoor public target range for firearm users in the District of Columbia. The grant amount for this project will not exceed $750,000 and the range must include firing lanes, classroom facilities for safety education, and retail sales offices. The Secretary of the Interior will allocate funds for an indoor public target range in the District of Columbia. The range must include retail sales offices for firearms and ammunition, secure storage for dealers, and other amenities appropriate for a public range. If the Mayor fails to apply for the grant or construct the range within the specified time frame, the Secretary will take over the construction and operation of the range. The District of Columbia can operate an indoor public firearms target range on Federal land using funds from the Federal aid to wildlife restoration fund. The ongoing operating costs can be covered by funds from the Federal aid to wildlife restoration fund, grants, or user fees. The District of Columbia can operate an indoor public firearms target range on Federal land using funds from the Federal aid to wildlife restoration fund. User fees charged for use of public target ranges should be comparable to commercial market rates and can also be used to raise funds from the public.
